did.abstract: Portraits of English poet John Keats and objects owned by him.

acqinfo.p: Various accessions, various dates. See item description for full acquisition information.

accessrestrict.p: The Keats Room and many of these objects can be viewed by guided tour Fridays at 2:00 p.m.
Examination of objects in the Houghton Reading Room requires advance notice, and the permission of the curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation for Publication:
prefercite.p: John Keats Portraits and Artifacts (Keats Room). Houghton Library, Harvard University.

bioghist.p: John Keats (1795-1821) was one of the principal poets of the English Romantic movement.
These objects, most of which are on permanent display in the Keats Room at Houghton Library, were acquired at various times and from various donors. Some items were owned by John Keats.

arrangement.p:
Organized into the following two series:
I. Portraits of John Keats
II. Objects owned by John Keats

scopecontent.p: Includes portraits of Keats: silhouette by Charles Armitage Brown (1819), bas-relief (sculpture) by Muriel Caswall (ca. 1945), portrait cameo in bone china (1970), three drawings by Joseph Severn (ca. 1818, 1830, 1860), and medallions by Sidney Waugh (1936); and mixed media by Ross Wilson. Also includes objects owned by Keats, including: gold bracelet (jewelry), gold seal with chain, tin box formerly housing a Book of Common Prayer (1817), locks of John Keats's hair (one in gold locket), and the prize medal awarded to Keats in 1810 while attending John Clarke's School in Enfield.

acqinfo.head: Provenance:
acqinfo.p: Label on back of frame: "This Sepia drawing of John Keats, the poet, by Severn, was presented to Dr. Samuel Steele of Abergavenny by Richard [sic] Trelawney, the friend of Byron, Shelley and Keats, when he was living at Cefn Ila, Usk, Mon., and was purchsed at the sale of the effects of Dr. D. Steele, son of Dr. Samuel Steele, at Abergavenny in 1902 by old James Barnes, a dealer of Newport, Mon. John Kyrle Fletcher purchased it from Barnes the day after the sale. The paper is watermarked 1829."
Accession entry continues: Purchased by Arthur A. Houghton, Jr. from Ifan Kyrle Fletcher in 1965.
Back of frame also with manuscript inscription: "Samuel Steele Esq MD."
*65M-13. Gift of Arthur A. Houghton, Jr., 715 Fifth Avenue, New York 22, New York; received: 1965 July 13.

acqinfo.p: *75-1447. Gift of Ella Keats Whiting, Mrs. C. Randolph Myer, John K. Whiting, Jr. '29, c/o Ella Keats Whiting, 17 Cottage Street, Wellesley, Massachusetts 02181; received: 1976 May.

physdesc.physfacet: gold link metal chain with clasp ;

note.p: In wooden case, with satin cushion.

Bracelet made from a portion of a gold chain originally given to Keats by an unidentified admirer. Keats gave it to his sister-in-law Georgiana, who thought it too long and shortened it by making one or more bracelets of the excess. Georgiana gave this bracelet to her daughter, Ella (Keats) Peay, who passed it along to her daughter, Mildred (Peay) Whiting, mother of the donors. [description written at time of accessioning].

note.p: Seal design is the letters "JK" with crown above and below letters (in semi-circular pattern); seal produces 2 x 2.5 cm. image.
In style of chain with fob.
